entry.content:
ENGLISH üá¨üáß (O'zbek tili pastda)

Question:

If the current tech is too weak to simulate a human behavior, what animal are there we can fully replicate it's intelligence?

1. Simple invertebrates ‚Äì full replication is almost achievable today

Animal Neurons Current replication status Notes
C. elegans (nematode worm) 302 ‚úÖ Full behavior replication in lab simulations Connectome fully mapped. Neural dynamics simulated in software; all motor/reflex behaviors reproducible.
Fruit fly (Drosophila larva) ~10,000 ‚ö†Ô∏è Partial replication Reflexes and simple motor patterns replicated. Adult fly: ~100,000 neurons ‚Üí only simple behaviors reproducible.

Scale: 10¬≤‚Äì10‚Åµ neurons
Tech: Standard neural simulation software, no nanotech required
Timeline to full adult fly replication: 5‚Äì10 years with current connectome mapping projects and computational power.

2. Insects with moderate complexity ‚Äì partial replication

Animal Neurons Status Notes
Ants/Bees 250,000 ‚Äì 1,000,000 ‚ö†Ô∏è Partial replication Foraging, pathfinding, and swarm behaviors replicated in robots and simulations. Full neural detail not captured.
Moths ~200,000 ‚ö†Ô∏è Partial Navigation and evasive flight partially replicated using robotics & sensors.

Scale: 10‚Åµ‚Äì10‚Å∂ neurons
Tech: Robotics + AI + partial neural emulation; nanotech sensors not required yet
Years until full neural replication: 15‚Äì30 years (assuming advances in connectomics, brain-wide imaging, and computational modeling).

3. Small vertebrates ‚Äì gross behavior only

Animal Neurons Status Notes
Zebrafish ~100,000 ‚Äì 1,000,000 ‚ö†Ô∏è Partial Swimming patterns, simple learning, and reflexes replicated in labs. Full perception/emotion unavailable.
Rodents (mouse) ~71 million ‚ö†Ô∏è Limited Maze navigation, basic decision-making replicable in AI models. Complex social/learning behavior not fully replicable.
Frogs ~16 million ‚ö†Ô∏è Limited Motor reflexes can be simulated; adaptive behavior partially understood.

Scale: 10‚Å∂‚Äì10‚Å∏ neurons
Tech: High-resolution imaging, optogenetics, AI simulations. Nanotech-based neuron-level reading/manipulation is under research.
Years until full behavioral replication: 50+ years realistically, unless nanotech and high-dimensional neural recording advance faster.

4. Complex mammals ‚Äì full replication currently impossible

Animal Neurons Status Notes
Dogs ~500 million ‚ùå Impossible Can replicate isolated tasks (pattern recognition, trained behaviors) with AI and robotics. Full cognition/emotion inaccessible.
Monkeys 6‚Äì7 billion ‚ùå Impossible Partial behavior studies possible in labs; full replication would require mapping entire brain and sensory system.
Humans ~86 billion ‚ùå Impossible Truly emergent behavior, consciousness, memory, and creativity cannot yet be replicated.

Scale: 10‚Å∏‚Äì10¬π¬π neurons
Tech: Hypothetical nanotech capable of real-time neuron reading/writing; quantum computation may accelerate high-dimensional simulation.
Years until even partial ‚Äúfull behavior replication‚Äù: 100+ years, likely only achievable with advanced nanotech and extremely high-dimensional computing.

5. Technology factors and requirements

Factor Current capability Future potential
Neural mapping Electron microscopy, optogenetics, connectomics (partial) Nanobots to read every synapse in vivo (~2040‚Äì2060)
Computation Supercomputers, cloud clusters (~10¬π‚Åµ FLOPS) Exascale (~10¬π‚Å∏ FLOPS) for mammalian brains; zettascale (~10¬≤¬π FLOPS) for humans
Nano-sensors / actuators Research stage Could allow real-time neuron-level replication and closed-loop simulation of complex animals
Storage 1‚Äì10 TB for worm/fruit fly neural data ~100 PB for human-scale connectome + dynamics

6. Key insights

  • We can fully replicate simple invertebrates today ‚Äî C. elegans is essentially ‚Äúsolved.‚Äù

  • For moderate insects, full neural replication is feasible in 15‚Äì30 years with current neuroscience and AI trends.

  • Small vertebrates may be partially replicable by mid-century.

  • Complex mammals and humans are orders of magnitude beyond current tech; full replication likely requires nanotech, extreme computational resources, and ultra high-dimensional simulation ‚Äî potentially a century away.

  • Emergent behaviors scale nonlinearly: doubling neurons multiplies complexity exponentially, not linearly.

O'zbek üá∫üáø

Savol:

Agar inson intellekti hozirgi texnologik resurslar bilan taqlid qilish qiyin bo‚Äòlsa, biz hozir qaysi hayvon aqlini haqiqatan ham takrorlay olamiz?

1. Oddiy umurtqasizlar ‚Äì to‚Äòliq takrorlash bugun deyarli erishilgan

Hayvon Neyronlar Hozirgi takrorlash holati Izohlar
C. elegans (nematod qurti) 302 ‚úÖ To‚Äòliq xatti-harakatlar laboratoriya simulyatsiyalarida takrorlangan Connectome to‚Äòliq xaritalangan. Neyron dinamikasi dasturiy ta‚Äôminotda simulyatsiya qilingan; barcha motor/refleks xatti-harakatlari takrorlanadigan.
Frukt pashshasi (Drosophila lichinkasi) ~10,000 ‚ö†Ô∏è Qisman takrorlash Reflekslar va oddiy motor naqshlari takrorlangan. Kattalar pashshasi: ~100,000 neyron ‚Üí faqat oddiy xatti-harakatlar takrorlanadigan.

Miqyos: 10¬≤‚Äì10‚Åµ neyron
Texnologiya: Standart neyron simulyatsiya dasturlari, nanotexnologiya talab qilinmaydi
Kattalar pashshasini to‚Äòliq takrorlash muddati: 5‚Äì10 yil, hozirgi connectome xaritalash loyihalari va hisoblash quvvati bilan.

2. O‚Äòrtacha murakkablikdagi hasharotlar ‚Äì qisman takrorlash

Hayvon Neyronlar Holati Izohlar
Chumolilar/Ari 250,000 ‚Äì 1,000,000 ‚ö†Ô∏è Qisman takrorlash Ov qilish, yo‚Äòl topish va to‚Äòda xatti-harakatlari robotlar va simulyatsiyalarda takrorlangan. To‚Äòliq neyron tafsilotlari qamrab olinmagan.
Kuya ~200,000 ‚ö†Ô∏è Qisman Navigatsiya va qochish parvozi qisman robototexnika va sensorlar yordamida takrorlangan.

Miqyos: 10‚Åµ‚Äì10‚Å∂ neyron
Texnologiya: Robototexnika + AI + qisman neyron emulyatsiyasi; nanotexnologiya sensorlari hali talab qilinmaydi
To‚Äòliq neyron takrorlashgacha yillar: 15‚Äì30 yil (connectomics, miya bo‚Äòylab tasvirlash va hisoblash modellashtirishdagi yutuqlarni hisobga olgan holda).

3. Kichik umurtqali hayvonlar ‚Äì faqat umumiy xatti-harakatlar

Hayvon Neyronlar Holati Izohlar
Zebrafish ~100,000 ‚Äì 1,000,000 ‚ö†Ô∏è Qisman Suzish naqshlari, oddiy o‚Äòrganish va reflekslar laboratoriyalarda takrorlangan. To‚Äòliq idrok/his-tuyg‚Äòular mavjud emas.
Kemiruvchilar (sichqon) ~71 million ‚ö†Ô∏è Cheklangan Labirint navigatsiyasi, asosiy qaror qabul qilish AI modellarida takrorlanadigan. Murakkab ijtimoiy/o‚Äòrganish xatti-harakati to‚Äòliq takrorlanmaydi.
Qurbaqalar ~16 million ‚ö†Ô∏è Cheklangan Motor reflekslari simulyatsiya qilinishi mumkin; moslashuvchan xatti-harakat qisman tushunilgan.

Miqyos: 10‚Å∂‚Äì10‚Å∏ neyron
Texnologiya: Yuqori aniqlikdagi tasvirlash, optogenetika, AI simulyatsiyalari. Nanotexnologiyaga asoslangan neyron darajasidagi o‚Äòqish/manipulyatsiya tadqiqot bosqichida.
To‚Äòliq xatti-harakat takrorlashgacha yillar: 50+ yil realistik, agar nanotexnologiya va yuqori o‚Äòlchamli neyron yozuvi tezroq rivojlanmasa.

4. Murakkab sut emizuvchilar ‚Äì to‚Äòliq takrorlash hozirda imkonsiz

Hayvon Neyronlar Holati Izohlar
Itlar ~500 million ‚ùå Imkonsiz Izolyatsiya qilingan vazifalarni (naqsh tanish, o‚Äòrgatilgan xatti-harakatlar) AI va robototexnika bilan takrorlash mumkin. To‚Äòliq idrok/his-tuyg‚Äòular erishib bo‚Äòlmaydi.
Maymunlar 6‚Äì7 milliard ‚ùå Imkonsiz Qisman xatti-harakat tadqiqotlari laboratoriyalarda mumkin; to‚Äòliq takrorlash butun miya va sensor tizimini xaritalashni talab qiladi.
Odamlar ~86 milliard ‚ùå Imkonsiz Haqiqiy emergent xatti-harakat, ong, xotira va ijodkorlik hali takrorlanmaydi.

Miqyos: 10‚Å∏‚Äì10¬π¬π neyron
Texnologiya: Har bir neyronni real vaqtda o‚Äòqish/yozishga qodir faraziy nanotexnologiya; kvant hisoblash yuqori o‚Äòlchamli simulyatsiyani tezlashtirishi mumkin.
Hatto qisman ‚Äúto‚Äòliq xatti-harakat takrorlash‚Äùgacha yillar: 100+ yil, ehtimol faqat ilg‚Äòor nanotexnologiya va o‚Äòta yuqori o‚Äòlchamli hisoblash bilan erishiladi.

5. Texnologiya omillari va talablari

Omil Hozirgi imkoniyat Kelajak potentsiali
Neyron xaritalash Elektron mikroskopiya, optogenetika, connectomics (qisman) Nanobotlar har bir sinapsni in vivo o‚Äòqish uchun (~2040‚Äì2060)
Hisoblash Superkompyuterlar, bulut klasterlari (~10¬π‚Åµ FLOPS) Ekzaskala (~10¬π‚Å∏ FLOPS) sut emizuvchilar miyasi uchun; zettaskala (~10¬≤¬π FLOPS) odamlar uchun
Nano-sensorlar / aktuatorlar Tadqiqot bosqichi Murakkab hayvonlarning real vaqtda neyron darajasidagi takrorlanishi va yopiq tsikl simulyatsiyasiga imkon berishi mumkin
Saqlash 1‚Äì10 TB qurt/frukt pashshasi neyron ma‚Äôlumotlari uchun ~100 PB odam miqyosidagi connectome + dinamika uchun

6. Asosiy tushunchalar

  • Biz oddiy umurtqasizlarni bugun to‚Äòliq takrorlay olamiz ‚Äî C. elegans deyarli ‚Äúhal qilingan‚Äù.
  • O‚Äòrtacha hasharotlar uchun to‚Äòliq neyron takrorlash 15‚Äì30 yilda hozirgi nevrologiya va AI tendentsiyalari bilan mumkin.
  • Kichik umurtqalilar asr o‚Äòrtalarida qisman takrorlanishi mumkin.
  • Murakkab sut emizuvchilar va odamlar hozirgi texnologiyadan buyuklik tartibida ortda; to‚Äòliq takrorlash nanotexnologiya, o‚Äòta yuqori hisoblash resurslari va o‚Äòta yuqori o‚Äòlchamli simulyatsiyani talab qiladi ‚Äî ehtimol bir asr uzoqda.
  • Emergent xatti-harakatlar chiziqli emas, balki eksponensial miqyosda o‚Äòsadi: neyronlarni ikki baravar oshirish murakkablikni eksponensial ko‚Äòpaytiradi.

entry.title: My Story
entry.content:
My name is Ruhiddin Turdaliyev, born on 28 June 2003 in the Fergana Valley of Uzbekistan. I grew up as a Kyrgyz native, bilingual in Uzbek, and gradually reached an English level around B2. My early education took place at local school No. 59 in the Fergana District, where I felt confident, even strong, compared to my classmates. But that confidence would be challenged soon.

After the 9th grade, I was accepted into the Academic Lyceum under TUIT Fergana branch, specializing in the technicians direction with a focus on math and physics. The moment I entered, I realized something painful: everything I knew was shallow compared to the competition-level students around me. They had deep foundations, while I was suddenly the one who knew nothing at all.

The first year was harsh. My results were the worst in the entire lyceum. At one point, the administration called my parent to the director‚Äôs office to warn that I would either improve immediately or be removed from the institution. I returned home only once a week, carrying the pressure of catching up to a world I had never imagined. Yet, in that difficult environment, I found loyal roommates and friends who stood with me, helped me understand subjects, and kept me from breaking under the weight.

Those two years (2019‚Äì2021) became a period of rebuilding myself from scratch. Day by day, topic by topic, I wrestled with math and physics until I almost reached the level of the best students in my class. By the end, I discovered that I loved physics more deeply than math. The lyceum awarded me a certificate as a ‚ÄúTechnical Programmer,‚Äù a small reminder of how far I had climbed.

When the national exam came, I scored 152.25 out of 189 and submitted five choices for university:

  1. Mathematics (NUU),
    2‚Äì5. Mathematics & Informatics in various universities.

I chose the ‚ÄúSirtqi‚Äù (part-time) format intentionally so I could study independently alongside university. I had wanted IT at TUIT, but fear of failure made me choose safer directions. Ironically, I did not expect to be accepted into my first choice at NUU in Pure Mathematics, yet that is where I landed, according to the rules that assign applicants to the highest successful option.

While studying in Tashkent, I spent my free time in Fergana continuing self-study. My parents supported me once again, buying me a laptop in December 2021 so I could learn IT seriously. In truth, my interests had long been drifting toward electronics, robotics, and automation, but these fields felt too young in Uzbekistan, with limited resources and weak education. So I began with something more accessible: web development.

I started with frontend. I learned HTML with heavy exhaustion, tried building a decent-looking website, only to feel that the time I spent had been wasted. Then I discovered CSS through Uzbek tutorials, practiced small pages, and slowly got better. But a realization struck: frontend felt shallow to me, too focused on design, not enough logic. I wanted depth, structure, reasoning. I wanted backend.

I began learning Java for its security, but I didn‚Äôt like the syntax and remembered seeing a more elegant language somewhere. So I turned to Python. I bought Python Basic and Python Advanced courses from PDP Academy for about $130. After completing them, I looked into the next modules, but the high cost and the one-year access limit discouraged me. I began searching for alternatives and found that the same-level Python content was freely available on YouTube through SariqDev.

That discovery shifted something in me. I realized many educational centers had turned learning into business. It became clear that without English, a person could not develop seriously. So I joined offline courses ‚Äî not one, but nearly ten different learning centers ‚Äî staying no more than 2.5 months at each because I was dissatisfied with progress, environment, or cost. No center gave me the energy, focus, or pressure that my lyceum days had given me. I understood that true results were coming from my own attempts, not from institutions.

That realization pushed me toward full self-study. My plan became simple: learn English well enough to open the gates to all other knowledge. Those months felt like wandering ‚Äî like a lost ant trying to find its destiny ‚Äî filled with valuable experiences that came at the cost of precious time.

During this period, I learned Django and backend development, but another issue arose: backend work was invisible. Even my parents could not see what I was doing, and IT was something completely new in the countryside. That made me decide to become a full-stack developer. I learned JavaScript, React, Redux, and even touched mobile development through React Native and Expo. I worked intensely, but my English remained a bottleneck.

In 2024, I finally reached the level where I could study English-language resources directly. Time then became my tightest constraint. Around this period, I also began listening to English Islamic lectures, especially from Nouman Ali Khan. This strengthened my comprehension, and it felt natural because Islam was already familiar to me. Along with that, I held a personal principle: to learn languages without adopting the behaviors or moral patterns of their cultures, so that I would not lose my own identity in the process.

In November 2024, I joined Velo Ijara, a small bike rental company in Tashkent, not just as a practical trainee but as the lead developer within the trainee framework. I worked there for eight months, handling the technical side while gaining real-world experience in a small but active environment.

Recently, I revisited electronics through YouTube lessons. Suddenly, the advanced physics theories I had learned in the lyceum connected with the physical devices I had never seen closely before. That combination gave me new hope of returning to this field someday.

I believe that if God permits, I can learn and do anything. But I also know my nature: I dive deeply into new subjects, absorb them fully, and then often feel overwhelmed by the amount of work needed to bring the ideas to life. Time, budget, and resources intimidate me. I do not think I will feel fulfilled working only as a regular employee; I am drawn toward craft, design, and invention. The conditions around me may not support these ambitions, but I still care about them. I share my ideas and paths not for fame, but because I want to see those ideas come alive in the real world, even if through someone else‚Äôs hands.
